Author: Spiderman#3141
Content: if i do an atomic swap of two ERC-20 tokens on barterdex, what happens to the fees collected?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: the fees will eventually be paid a revenue to DEX holders

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: ERC-20 -> Converted to KMD -> KMD 50% Disctributed to DEX Holders

Author: Spiderman#3141
Content: how is it converted to KMD? what if there is no liquidity? what's a DEX holder?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content:
it will be sold  on a exchange like BarterDEX. if there is no liquidity it might not worth doing it for that token erc20 token.
DEX Holders are Owners of the DEX coin it's an assetchain with receives dividends from the fees

Author: Spiderman#3141
Content: so what happens to the fees collected if there is nobody trading the ERC-20 for KMD? just sits there until liquidity comes?

Author: Spiderman#3141
Content: by DEX coin do you mean InstantDEX?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: fees will sit there,unless it is so big it is worth using a differnet exchange to convert

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: yes it was called instantDEX on NXT

Author: Spiderman#3141
Content: okay cool. and once it's converted to KMD, 50% goes to instantDEX holders ?

Author: Spiderman#3141
Content: what happens to the other 50%?

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content:
15% to JUMBLR 15% to BOTS 5% to REVS 5% to MGW 5% operating costs 5% Promotions
that is the info I have but it might change

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 10% goes to GUI used for the swap, so the last 2 5% got changed

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: Is there anywhere detailing the attacks (or lack there of) that malicious notaries can perform on Komodo? It seems the worst they can do is stop notarization of Komodo? Is there anywhere detailing why a minimum of 13 online notaries is needed?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: If all the notaries got together and colluded, they could at worst simply refuse to notarize the chain?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: Also, what percentage of blocks are mined by notaries?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the power of notaries is to notarize, but these have to be valid, so yes, the worset appears to be a witholding of notarization, which is a degrading of security, but visible to all.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 13 is based on the experimental results of needing a majority to be in sync to be able to get 13, it is quite a complex stochasitc process to choose the random 13 of 64 eah round

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries mine approx 75% of blocks

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
Regarding the discussion that happened with @ProficieNt :  Mostly the scalable asset chains are going to be used for utility/app tokens. The main function miners provide are validation(Checking the transactions are valid and making blocks), security based on decentralization(i.e., if one miner is bad(submitting invalid blocks), the rest of the miners won't accept his blocks), redundancy: some miners go offline - others can continue mining making the system resilient and large hash power (to protect from 51% attacks). 51% attacks are mainly double spend attacks - can be ignored for dPOW if the last notarizid block is considered as valid. As resulted from the  above discussion, a miner with large hash power can only attack by censoring transactions. Can the other miners simply block and stop accepting his blocks? For other block-chains this won't be feasible because the large hash rate is required for protection, but with dPOW this is less of an issue? 

Another conclusion was that by splintering into a huge number of chains, we are breaking up POW and POS security both by breakung up hash power and stake/wealth , I don't know about POS, but can't all the asset chains be merge mined so that all of them get the combined hash power?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: The problem is, who decides when the chain gets notarized? How will the user know which chain to guest?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: I think that the success of blockchains to provide trustless transactions and all the desirable properties is due to equal parts technical things and social/behavioral/game theoretic things. So for this problem too I think some form of hybrid social+technical solution exists and we just need to think it out.

Author: jorian#4555
Content: math decides when the chain gets notarized, right? after around 5 blocks of the chain that is being notarized, a notarization happens

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @gcharang the core problem here is that Komodo uses PoW (only true consensus algo atm) and that you cant split PoW and still enjoy your security unless you have randomized assignment

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: that said, as a security platform for independent PoW chains it's pretty cool

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @jl777c How does Komodo's difficulty algorithm work? It actively tries to award notaries 75% of the blocks, right? What happens if all notaries stopped mining, or if notaries started attempting censorship attacks / short range attacks?

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: I've always looked at the starting of an asset chain, not as splitting and pulling hash power away from Komodo, but adding hash power to the asset chain that didn't exist in the Komodo ecosystem yet. I thought when you set up an assetchain, it is your chain, all mining operations you must provide, or create incentive for others to mine the chain. So in this way it's not sharding Komodo and its mining power, but is simply adding a new chain that notarizes its blocks to Komodo, and in this way isn't like an ERC20 token. The asset chain could have small hash power and susceptible to censorship but the dPoW mitigates this threat by requiring the censoring party to either time their 51% control with notary hashes, or maintain it indefinitely. I'm not too sure on how the inclusion of PoS hybrid to prevent this (though I assume it's to create more mining power to supplement few miners on the chain). but beyond that it's over my head

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content:
Choose one of two:
 - Komodo is the world's most scalable blockchain through its asset chains.
 - Komodo is a hub providing security and interoperability to independent chains.

It appears the team is working towards number 2 but it seems the community is claiming Komodo has achieved point 1

Content: #FalseDichotomy

Author: ProficieNt#3097

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: "Choose one of two" implies that both can't be true and/or there can be an nth option
